review.title: Towards Formal Fault Tree Analysis using Theorem Proving
review.abstract: Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) is a dependability analysis technique that has been widely used to predict reliability, availability and safety of many complex engineering systems. Traditionally, these FTA-based analyses are done using paper-and-pencil proof methods or computer simulations, which cannot ascertain absolute correctness due to their inherent limitations. As a complementary approach, we propose to use the higher-order-logic theorem prover HOL4 to conduct the FTA-based analysis of safety-critical systems where accuracy of failure analysis is a dire need. In particular, the paper presents a higher-order-logic formalization of generic Fault Tree gates, i.e., AND, OR, NAND, NOR, XOR and NOT and the formal verification of their failure probability expressions. Moreover, we have formally verified the generic probabilistic inclusion-exclusion principle, which is one of the foremost requirements for conducting the FTA-based failure analysis of any given system. For illustration purposes, we conduct the FTA-based failure analysis of a solar array that is used as the main source of power for the Dong Fang Hong-3 (DFH-3) satellite.

sections.heading: 4 Formalization of Probabilistic Inclusion-Exclusion Principle
sections.text: The probabilistic inclusion exclusion principle (PIE) forms an integral part of the reasoning involved in verifying the probability of error in an FT. In FTA, all the basic error events that can cause the occurrence of the system failure event are first identified, and these error events are then combined to model the general error behavior of the given system by using the error genres. [25] These combinations of the basic error events, known as cut sets, are then reduced to minimal cut sets (MCS), using some set theory rules such as idempotent, associative and commutative [25]. At this point, the PIE principle is used to evaluate the overall error probability of the given system based on the MCS events. If Ai is the i th fundamental error event or a combination of error events, then the error probability of the given system can be expressed.

sections.heading: 5 Application: Satellite’s Solar Array
sections.text: The arrays used in satellite missions are usually displayed in a folded position during the launch phase [5]. Once the satellite is in orbit, the arrays are deployed and the goal is to orient them all the time toward the Sun to maximize power generation for the satellite [5]. Errors in the solar field are mainly caused by the mechanical components that drive these mechanisms related to driving, deployment, locking, and orientation. [5] The solar array is normally driven by the use of a torsional burst [5]. Whereas, the closed cable loop (CCL), and the stepping or servo motors are used during the synchronization and orientation phases [5]. An FT can therefore be constructed by taking into account the faults in these mechanical components, which are the fundamental causes of satellite system failure.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The accuracy of error analysis is an urgent need for safety and mission critical applications where faulty error analysis can lead to catastrophic situations, including loss of life or severe financial setbacks. In this paper, we have presented a precise FTA approach based on higher order theoretical evidence to tackle the analysis of such critical systems. In particular, the paper presents a formalization of the commonly used FT gates and the PIE principle, which are the most important foundations for formal considerations about FTA within solid theorem evidence. As a case study, the paper also presents the formal error analysis of a satellite solar array. Building on the results presented in this paper, other FT gates, such as priority and tuning gates, can be formally modeled, and thus the scope of FTA-based formal reliability analysis [32] can be further improved. Some interesting applications in the real world that may benefit from our transports systems [3] and other avionics systems [3] can facilitate.
